review_title: Better than other VR Anatomy apps - Med1
one_reviews_text:
Right now all I can say is that this is better for learning anatomy for medschool than the higher rated VR anatomy apps. Comments about the UI are sort of irrelevant. Other Anatomy apps with better reviews have great UIs but completely lack content. If you are a med student studying gross anatomy, you need to be able to learn all of the muscles (and their attachments), nerves, veins, arteries, and lymphatics (as opposed to just the main organ systems). Still, there are some completely necessary features that would be VERY high yield for studying gross anatomy for med students. 

1. A quiz mode would be extremely beneficial. More than just give the name of the bone/organ/vein/etc but describe the attachments/innervations/embryology. 

2. Right now portions are sectioned by system. Cadaver anatomy is not sectioned by system, but by region. It would be helpful to be able to load an entire thorax and then to run through the disection that way. Additionally, a "whole body" mode would be extremely helpful. It's nice to be able to review the muscles but without seeing the nerves at the same time, I'm afraid it just doesn't compare to other resources. 

Overall a great app for learning gross anatomy at the med school level but severely lacking due to the omission of a few vital (and somewhat simple to implement I would imagine) features.

review_title: The free version on Oculus is better.
one_reviews_text:
I have to say I was sorely disppointed with this product and wish I could get a refund.  There is no turorial to assist you in learning how to use the product.  Further more I cannot find a way to rotate a view or move myself behind the object I wish to view.  The object is always presented just outside of the area where you can move around.  I tired to write the company about this, but the email system, that is only available on their website, just keeps giving an error message.  Don't waste you money.

Originally I downloaded the free version of another anatomy program.  It is not as in depth, but you can manipulate the image, rotate it, look under it, look inside it and you can change your point of view with a single click.  Watching the cardiac cycle or the pacreatic operation is very cool.  Use the free service and don't waste your money on this product.
Terrible. The GUI sucks. I cant go indepth on the bones. Nothing is clear. DO NOT BUY. You will get more from your money by just buying a book and learn more too.

review_title: The interface needs to be updated
one_reviews_text: The interface needs to be updated to use the oculus touch controller instead of an xbox controller.  This is not an xbox game.

Great app!  To clear up confusion, the body IS in stereoscopic 3D.  The ENVIRONMENT is not.  It's actually nicer to switch to floating in empty space rather than the weird painted-on conference room scene, which can make me ill if I move around too much.  The only reason I don't give 5 stars is the lack of action animations for the personal edition (this app), particularly muscles.  It's available on the enterprise edition, so why not include it here for everyone?  Will update to 5 stars when/if that becomes available.

review_title: Shows promise, needs VR UI work
one_reviews_text: I would love this and give it 5 stars if it had a good touch/VR UI.  The game pad thing is kinda lame.  On the other hand, there is a good amount of anatomy content.  Devs, great content here, just make an oculus rift/touch worthy UI!  I would happily play double or triple the price for a good UI and gradually adding more content (e.g. muscles in articulation, things like hip glide, et cetera, teaching me positional nomenclature like lateral, medial, et cetera).
Fails to start all the times!

Yet another problem is the 'go back to the menu' button which will re-start the programm instead of sending you back to the sub catagory menu.. wtf.. The last problem i 'found' :S is the programm doesn't seem to remember what environment you choose before the 'go back to the menu' button. awkward right? You would think that an app like this should suffer from these minority's but it does.. Aside from these it find it an price possesion for everyone

review_title: NOT the version advertised on Steam
one_reviews_text:
There's a version of this for HTC Vive and it is NOT this version.  Do not expect to be able to manipulate the body with your controllers.  Note the Touch simulating gamepad...and don't make the same mistake I did.  

Oh and the app sucks.  Just...ugly, and with a terrible user interface.

Kind of odd that this app is not true stereoscopic 3D, considering that you have to wear a headset to use it. Wearing a headset makes it difficult to take notes, consult reference works while you use the app, etc. so it seems the very least they should do is make it true 3D. You get the drawbacks of wearing a cumbersome headset on your head without the advantages.

"The application is created for curious minds, medical and allied-health students, educators, patients, and healthcare professionals. "

As a healthcare professional I can say that the level of anatomical detail in this app is woefully lacking and the developer's insinuation that it will be of use to medical and allied-health personnel is blantantly false. The user interface is unintuitive and painful to navigate and itself would be enough reason to give a 1 star. Complete waste of money.

Great aid for understanding human anatomy and making the essential connections to clinical correlations.
Useful for improving parient care too. Happy with the UI, easy to use.
very disappointed

Haven't Muscle Actions. 
This app only have Muscle Attachments and Skeleton Views, too simple. The free app "The Body VR", have the Muscle Attachments and Skeleton Views, too.
Why we are buy this app? Because, we want the app have professional function.

For conveniant handling, the adding of support for Oculus Touch is a must. 

The zoom and rotation via Gamepad is not very smooth and it's not easy to adjust views precisely. In general navigation within the models should be optimized to be more conveniant. In my opinion a good way to navigate: when it would be possible to drag, zoom and rotate models like models in MEDIUM. 

A function to disable the cursor or set its transparency or size should be implemented too, because the cursor is sometimes hiding details you look at.

When this is done I will give 5 stars.

Good performance with GTX970.

UPDATE: I saw the Steam version has way better implementation of Vive controllers and interactivity. In comparisson the Rift version is not recommended at the moment.
Could be great - once they add Touch support. As long as they don't - pass for now and wait.

I love this, but I second (or third) the extant motions to enable the Oculus Touch controllers for this product.  I'm also looking for an affordable surgery simulator (that isn't a joke or gag, but something technically accurate).  Thanks to the developers of this simulation, keep up the great work.
What an app! This really gave essence to my Rift. I got amazed by the anatomy detail included.  Easy to use and endless detail to study,

review_title: Amazing-A must have for medical students
one_reviews_text: The controls take some getting used to but the amount of detail and content provided is astonishing. I wish I had this back in college when taking anatomy. It's fantastic. I expected some 3d anatomy figures you can look at but this gives you in depth detail about all anatomical structures of the body. Want to know the origin and iserition points of the platysma? What about innervation and blood supply too? It's there! Seriously this is a great too for students! Get it now!

review_title: Terrible with the gamepad. Needs touch.
one_reviews_text:
Currently not worth 15$ at all. Desperatly needs Touch support and a lot of patches.

1) No translational movement possible. Say I want to inspect the lower digestive system, I really can't but rotate the model with his feet pointed at me and then start zooming in.
What leads to the second main issue:
2) The speed of zoom is terrible! It makes me nauseous. Even the most subtle bending of the right stick, catapults me toward or away from the model.
3) Overall, the way to interact with the model is flawed, making me nauseous after minutes. It feels like I would rotate around it, instead of spinning it in front of me.
This could have been fixed easily, by some static scene like a prep room. Instead I am floating in the white Matrix load scene.
4) The models are way too huge in their 3D environment. This leads to the sensation, of standing still while actually moving away or towards the model. At first impression I thought I had bought a GearVR app. Again, making me sick.

Minor issues are:
5) A press of the [START] button of the gamepad restarts the program, [SELECT] does nothing. I want to go to the menu, over one of these buttons!! To go there I have to press [B], focus on the icon for the menu and finish with [A].
6) The gamepad's triggers have no functionality assigned. They could have been used for translation (linear movement).
7) Can' say too much by now, as I couldn't stay long, but the possibilities of preping the body are very minor. I can't make certain categories transparent, only remove them completly by pressing [A] while focusing them.
As this is the first anatomy program for the Rift and cheap if compared to printed anatomy books, I don't criticize it, but mention it nonetheless, as I expect it from the next anatomy VR program I'll buy.

MISC:
8) It's all static. No problem, totally OK for 15$.
9) Poor synthetic voice reading the Latin names of body parts, tissue and bone. No problem again for 15$, don't expect any voice at all.

If you're learning anatomy its a no brainer, very detailed and insanely cheap for what you get. However - The Zoom and rotation sensitivity on the xbox controller is insanely sensitive, they just need to address this and they'd make lots of people happy.
Great graphics but lacks the touch interactivity of the HTC version which is a huge selling point.

I'm a medical student and this app is very helpful to create a more immersive anatomy learning experience! I hope touch controller support with be added in the future with the added functionality to be able to manipulate structures.
This is the most immersive way to learn human anatomy. The controls are agile and functional. Supplied descriptive texts are great. Excellent level of detail on models and beautiful graphics!

Blown away by the detailed anatomy that features this app. It's fantastic for helping me visualize the position of muscles. nerves, and vessels in relation to each other so much easier. I've never seen something like that before! It's very informative, and simple to operate.
This VR app is simply awesome. It has everything you need to get hold with anatomical sciences. I wish this tech was available a few years ago when I did my physio degree..

This VR app is pretty amazing. If you're studying at school, university, college or out of curiosity this app will help. All anatomical structures are there for virtual dissection and exploration. Easy to use, Great work!

This anatomy app is a great learning tool. It eliminates need to study from physical models and massive books. I love how agile is when exploring different bodyparts and presenting detailed information about them. Would recommend it to everyone. Well worth the money!

As a dental student, I must say this is simply the best way to visualize anatomy, ever. I love the preconfigured regional anatomy in this app. They cover every body part and pair similar drawings I've seen in atlases. Blown away the detail and text descriptions. I would love to test it with Oculus controllers once they hit the market.
The interactivity is simply amazing. You have control to view from every angle and with great detail. Very professional, stunning graphics, appropriate controls.
